bibl.title: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Mazyck P. Ravenel, September 28, 1925

div1.p: Kean agrees that Russell should be unambiguous in his statements regarding Gorgas.

div1.head: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Mazyck P. Ravenel, September 28, 1925
div1.opener:
September 28, 1925.
Dr. Mazyck P. Ravenel,
University of Missouri,
Columbia, Missouri.
My dear Dr. Ravenel:
div1.p:
No I have not seen Dr. Russell's address in the
Sigma Xi Quarterly. If he makes the statement that General
Gorgas cleaned up Havana in 90 days, I imagine that he re-
fers to mosquito work only. The period mentioned would
seem to indicate it but it is to be regretted that the state-
ment is not specific enough to be clear. I expect to see
Russell in about ten days when I will be in New York attend-
ing the annual meeting of The Association of Military Surgeons
and I will ask him about it. He certainly should know all
the details of Reed's work and with his high standing as a
scientist it would be very regrettable for him to make state-
ments which are ambiguous. I am sure that he would be very
far from ever saying anything to detract from Reed's credit.
I remember very well Reed's telling me about the observation
of Dr. Henry F. Carter as to what was afterwards named the
extrinsic period of incubation in the mosquito, but it is my
recollection that he had decided to investigate the question
of the transmission of yellow fever by mosquitoes before this.
He spoke to General Sternberg about the investigation of
Finlay's theory before he went to Cuba and General Sternberg
authorized him to do so if he wished but stated that he thought
it would be a waste of time.

I hope you will write to Dr. Russell because it will
attract his attention to the importance of being accurate and
specific in these important details of medical history.
div1.closer:
Very sincerely yours, J. R. KEAN
Colonel, U.S. Army, Retired
Editor. JRK/W
